passages.text: Deutsche Bank Research
Indonesia: 2026 Budget deficit likely to slip, but stay within \(3\%\) limit

President Prabowo announced Indonesia's 2026 budget deficit at \(2.48\%\) of GDP in RAPBN'26. (Figure 1) While still within the \(3\%\) ceiling, we see the risks on net being a slippage to \(- 2.7\%\) of GDP, with the risk of undershooting on revenues larger than that on spending. The administration would likely want to keep to their spending plans to support growth, including through reallocations to other functions such as Economy or Social Protection, especially if allocations to the larger programmes such as free school meals (MBG) are underspent. (Figure 7)

Our estimated fiscal impulse from the 2026 draft budget is a slight drag at \(- 0.1\%\) of GDP, compared to the marginally positive \(+0.6\%\) in both 2024 and 2025. (Figure 2) Consequently, we think that the official \(5.4\%\) real GDP growth target for 2026 (DB: \(5\%\) ) could be difficult to achieve, given the currently muted sentiment in domestic private demand and the likely slowdown in global trade and demand.

The budget projects total revenue growth of \(9.8\%\) vs the average of \(1.5\%\) in 2024- 25. The projection is mainly driven by non- O&G income tax (personal, corporate) and VAT. We think that this target may be too optimistic given current economic conditions; \(- 6\%\) revenue growth could be more achievable on our estimate that GDP growth may be slower than the official target. While expenditure is allocated to rise by \(7.3\%\) mainly to the Education, Economy, and Defense functions—there may be some difficulties in scaling up spending, especially in MBG (IDR121tn in 2025 to 335tn in 2026). Spending could thus come below target in 2026 (we think \(5.4\%\) spending growth) and with our forecasted revenue growth of \(- 6\%\) , the overall deficit could reach about \(2.7\%\) of GDP. We look into the revenue and expenditure detail in the following sections.
Figure 1: Fiscal balance forecasts

Budget, IDR tn2025 OutlookRAPBN'26DB'26Revenue2,8663,1483,034- Incomes1,1021,2811,212- VAT891995962- Ngn-tax477455454- Other revenues396416406- Expenditure3,5283,7863,719- Central govt2,6633,1363,069- Transfers to regions864650650Balance-662-639-686Balance, % GDP-2.78-2.48-2.66
Source: Deutsche Bank Research, MoF
Figure 2: Fiscal impulse slightly negative in 2026
Source: Deutsche Bank Research, MoF, Haver Analytics

The \(9.8\%\) revenue growth target for 2026 may be too optimistic, in our view, especially as the government confirmed that it had no plans to introduce new types of taxes next year. While there could be amendments to the proposal before the budget is finalized in October, we think the revenue target would remain as is, unless the macroeconomic assumptions change. Revenue growth of \(\sim 6\%\) could be more achievable on our estimate that GDP growth may not rise as much as the official forecast projects, but nonetheless supported by improved tax collection efficiency. Instead of new taxes, the government intends to focus on reforming tax collection with the use of the CoreTax system implemented in early- 2025, along with other internal process improvements.

Revenue growth over 2024- 25 averaged \(1.5\%\) . (Figure 3) The sluggish revenue in 2024 was mainly due to shifts in the commodity and exports cycle (Figure 4), which weighed on revenues from natural resources. In 2025, the drag primarily stemmed from SOE dividends, which were routed to Danantara.
Figure 3: Revenue growth by category
Source:Deutsche Bank Research,MoF
Figure 4: Sluggish exports in 2023-24 weighed on government revenue
Source:Deutsche Bank Research,Haver Analytics
In our view, the key risks to the government's projections are from income taxes and VAT, the two main contributors to revenue.

Income tax: We looked at the sum of Non- O&G Income Tax (Pendapatan Pph Nonmigas) and Other Taxes (Pendapatan Pajak Lainnya) for RAPBN'26, as the Other Taxes category includes figures from a (pre- paid) tax deposit service that was introduced in conjunction with the implementation of CoreTax. While MoF forecasts a \(15.7\%\) increase in Non- O&G Income Tax to IDR1,154tn in 2026, when taken together with Other Taxes the growth would be an even higher \(16.3\%\) increase to 1,281tn (5% GDP in 2026 from \(4.6\%\) in 2025). We think a more conservative \(10\%\) growth here in 2026, vs the official 2025 Outlook of \(9.6\%\) could be more plausible. (Figure 5)

Indonesia's tax base remains shallow at \(12\%\) of GDP vs Asia's average of \(19.6\%\) , according to the OECD. Of the 148 million people in the labor force in 2023, only about 60 million were in the formal sector ( \(59\%\) of labor force in informal sector), of which \(\sim 13\) million paid income taxes. We estimate that \(\sim 40\% /60\%\) of income taxes are from personal and

corporate income, respectively. Media reports suggest that the labor market has been hit with layoffs in the formal sector. This could drive more workers into the informal sector and/or lead to more dropping below the middle class, with concomitant effects on personal income taxes.
Figure 5: Pre-paid tax deposits caused surge in Other Taxes
Source: Deutsche Bank Research, MoF
Figure 6: VAT sharply fell in 2025 amid significant refunds
Source: Deutsche Bank Research, Haver Analytics

VAT: With no new taxes proposed for 2026 and the muted consumption outlook ahead, we think that \(7 - 8\%\) growth in VAT revenue in 2026—broadly in line with 2024 and 2025—could be more attainable instead of the \(11.7\%\) target in RAPBN'26. Note that even in 2025, VAT collected in June YTD recorded a \(19.7\%\) YoY decline, primarily due to restitutions/refunds from VAT overpayments. (Figure 6) Slowing retail sales could also have contributed to the decline, with growth in H1 2025 at \(1.8\%\) YoY vs \(3.2\%\) for both halves of 2024.

Alternatively, the government could reconsider its plan to increase the general VAT to \(12\%\) from \(11\%\) , instead of just on luxury items currently, while keeping VAT on necessities at \(0\%\) . The government estimated that such an increase would have raised about 75tn in additional revenue. The regressive nature of VAT could be offset by improving the systems that facilitate social aid to needy households, as it recently announced.

Total expenditure is forecast to rise by \(7.3\%\) in RAPBN'26, picking up from \(5\%\) in 2025 but broadly in line with the \(7.6\%\) in 2024. The slowdown in 2025 was primarily due to budget efficiency measures implemented in H1. There could be some reallocations as the Budget Committee (Banggard) deliberates on priorities in the lead up to finalization. If any, we may see some reallocations from the free school meals programme (MBG)—given the realized difficulties in scaling up the needed logistics and infrastructure so far—into the Economy and/or Social Protection functions—where arguably greater public policy support is needed to spur domestic demand and where there could be faster realization of multiplier effects. (Figure 7)
MBG was initially budgeted for 171tn in 2025, but only 5tn had been disbursed as of June and it was reduced to 121tn for the year. The MBG allocation for 2026
28 August 2025 Asia Economic Notes
is IDR335tn. If we assume that MBG is underspent at \(268tn^1\) in 2026, then spending could rise by \(5.4\%\) instead of \(7.3\%\) , and the overall deficit could reach 689.4tn, or \(2.7\%\) of GDP.

There are also other uncertainties on expenditure, such as whether the budget efficiency programme will continue in 2026 thereby further cutting down on spending, as FM Sri Mulyani earlier signalled. Such reductions could come from the Public Services function (IDR793tn allocated), or energy subsidies (210tn), especially if oil prices remain below the government's assumption of US \(70 / \text{barr}\) in 2026. The Indonesia Crude Price averaged US \(69 in July 2025, compared to US\) 82 in APBN'25 assumptions. For context, according to the 2025 Outlook, 120tn was cut from the Public Services (0.5% of GDP) and 41tn from Economy (0.2%) functions vs APBN'25 allocations. These funds were partially reallocated to Defense (79.1tn; 0.3%) and Security (19.4tn; 0.1%).
Figure 7: Expenditure by main functions
Source: Deutsche Bank Research, MoF

Macroeconomic fluctuations often account for most of the risks associated with exposures to instruments that promise to pay fixed or variable interest rates. For an investor who is long fixed- rate instruments (thus receiving these cash flows), increases in interest rates naturally lift the discount factors applied to the expected cash flows and thus cause a loss. The longer the maturity of a certain cash flow and the higher the move in the discount factor, the higher will be the loss. Upside surprises in inflation, fiscal funding needs, and FX depreciation rates are among the most common adverse macroeconomic shocks to receivers. But counterparty exposure, issuer creditworthiness, client segmentation, regulation (including changes in assets holding limits for different types of investors), changes in tax policies, currency convertibility (which may constrain currency conversion, repatriation of profits and/or liquidation of positions), and settlement issues related to local clearing houses are also important risk factors. The sensitivity of fixed- income instruments to macroeconomic shocks may be mitigated by indexing the contracted cash flows to inflation, to FX depreciation, or to specified interest rates - these are common in emerging markets. The index fixings may - by construction - lag or mis- measure the actual move in the underlying variables they are intended to track. The choice of the proper fixing (or metric) is particularly important in swaps markets, where floating coupon rates (i.e., coupons indexed to a typically short- dated interest rate reference index) are exchanged for fixed coupons. Funding in a currency that differs from the currency in which coupons are denominated carries FX risk. Options on swaps (swaptions) the risks typical to options in addition to the risks related to rates movements.

Backtested, hypothetical or simulated performance results have inherent limitations. Unlike an actual performance record based on trading actual client portfolios, simulated results are achieved by means of the retroactive application of a backtested model itself designed with the benefit of hindsight. Taking into account historical events the backtesting of performance also differs from actual account performance because an actual investment strategy may be adjusted any time, for any reason, including a response to material, economic or market factors. The backtested performance includes hypothetical results that do not reflect the reinvestment of dividends and other earnings or the deduction of advisory fees, brokerage or other commissions, and any other expenses that a client would have paid or actually paid. No representation is made that any trading strategy or account will or is likely to achieve profits or losses similar to those shown. Alternative modeling techniques or assumptions might produce significantly different results and prove to be more appropriate. Past hypothetical backtest results are neither an indicator nor guarantee of future returns. Actual results will vary, perhaps materially, from the analysis.

The method for computing individual E,S,G and composite ESG scores set forth herein is a novel method developed by the Research department within Deutsche Bank AG, computed using a systematic approach without human intervention. Different data providers, market sectors and geographies approach ESG analysis and incorporate the findings in a variety of ways. As such, the ESG scores referred to herein may differ from equivalent ratings developed and implemented by other ESG data providers in the market and may also differ from equivalent ratings developed and implemented by other divisions within the Deutsche Bank Group. Such ESG scores also differ from other ratings and rankings that have historically been applied in research reports published by Deutsche Bank AG. Further, such ESG scores do not represent a formal or official view of Deutsche Bank AG.

It should be noted that the decision to incorporate ESG factors into any investment strategy may inhibit the ability to participate in certain investment opportunities that otherwise would be consistent with your investment objective and other principal investment strategies. The returns on a portfolio consisting primarily of sustainable investments may be lower or higher than portfolios where ESG factors, exclusions, or other sustainability issues are not considered, and the investment opportunities available to such portfolios may differ. Companies may not necessarily meet high performance standards on all aspects of ESG or sustainable investing issues; there is also no guarantee that any company will meet expectations in connection with corporate responsibility, sustainability, and/or impact performance.
